entry.title: How we stop cement ruining the climate

media:group.media:title: How we stop cement ruining the climate
media:group.media:description:
Cement is the second most consumed commodity on Earth. That's a problem. Learn more about the climate crisis with CuriosityStream and Nebula: https://www.curiositystream.com/simonclark
Our carbon emissions are overwhelmingly from our use and generation of energy, which means that our response to the climate crisis largely needs to be the decarbonisation of energy, specifically ending our dependence on fossil fuels. However, around one quarter of all our emissions come from other processes, one of the largest of which is construction. These emissions are mostly from cement production, due to the nature of making cement. In this video I shine a light on one company - LEILAC - who are developing what I think is a realistic, scalable solution to this problem. Which, in what may be a surprise to some, involves carbon capture technology. I also ask how a company has made a business model out of preventing carbon emissions, and what this tells us about how capitalism can respond to the climate crisis.
References (1) https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector (2) https://youtu.be/l3ed4v4tBhA (3) https://youtu.be/UOd-Jgly9Us
Disclaimer: I have not been paid by LEILAC or its parent company Calix to make this video. LEILAC reached out and asked if I'd be interested in covering their technology, and I was given total editorial freedom to make this video.
More about LEILAC: https://www.leilac.com/

entry.title: The scariest climate science paper I've ever read?

media:group.media:title: The scariest climate science paper I've ever read?
media:group.media:description:
Learn more about how the natural world works with Brilliant: https://www.brilliant.org/simonclark
This month a paper came out that honestly chilled me. It was about tipping points in climate - a well-known concept that the climate can change abruptly if certain conditions are met in certain elements of the climate system, such as excess melting of the Greenland ice sheet. That wasn't new. What was new was the threshold these tipping elements could flip - according to this research, we could be triggering some tipping elements already - and if we warm the planet by just 1.5°C then we are *likely* to do so.
The climate is still within our control. But if we keep emitting as we are, that isn't always going to be the case.
Every. Tenth. Of. A. Degree. Counts.
References: 1. https://journals.ametsoc.org/view/journals/clim/18/22/jcli3587.1.xml 2. https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.0705414105 3. http://sciencepolicy.colorado.edu/students/envs_4800/russill_2009.pdf 4. https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.abn7950 5. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UOd-Jgly9Us

Video about tipping points in climate and a new paper about climate tipping points, talking about the shutdown of the thermohaline circulation, permafrost thaw, collapse of ice sheets, and extinction of corals. This new paper from McKay et al showed that there isn't a neat relationship between cumulative carbon emissions and global warming - there can be step changes thanks to internal variability, rapidly pushing the Earth into different climates. In this video I talk about climate tipping points, how some are already possible today, and will become likely at just 1.5C of warming.

entry.title: Was England really warmer in medieval times?

media:group.media:title: Was England really warmer in medieval times?
media:group.media:description:
Get to grips with how the natural world really works with Brilliant! https://www.brilliant.org/simonclark
This video topic was picked by my patrons! Help me make more videos like this one by becoming a patron at http://www.patreon.com/simonoxfphys
The recent extreme heat in Europe has led many people on my social feeds to claim that England used to be warmer in the so-called "medieval warm period" than today, and so that any modern heat isn't worrying. In this video I look through the evidence often cited for this claim and discuss why the medieval warm period wasn't that warm, and certainly wasn't global. In short: we should still be very, very worried.
References in this video: 1. http://www.meteo.psu.edu/holocene/public_html/shared/articles/MannetalScience09.pdf 2. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1401-2 3. https://www.blogs.uni-mainz.de/fb09climatology/files/2012/03/Esper_2012_NatureCC6.pdf 4. https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~rjsw/ScottishPine/PDFs/Wilson2009.pdf 5. https://crudata.uea.ac.uk/~timo/datapages/mxdtrw.htm 6. https://web.archive.org/web/20200310164209/https://repository.arizona.edu/bitstream/handle/10150/621352/JQSR-D-16-00018R1.pdf;jsessionid=9B8B7F76B023F4E572425DD0964189A0?sequence=1 7. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature_record_of_the_last_2,000_years#/media/File:2000+_year_global_temperature_including_Medieval_Warm_Period_and_Little_Ice_Age_-_Ed_Hawkins.svg

entry.title: Why Europe is now a heatwave hotspot

media:group.media:title: Why Europe is now a heatwave hotspot
media:group.media:description:
The atmosphere runs on fluid mechanics! As explained on https://www.brilliant.org/simonclark
In July 2022 the UK shattered its temperature record, observing a temperature of over 40°C for the first time. This was part of a devastating heatwave that spanned the UK, France, Germany, Spain, and Portugal and saw evacuations, wildfires, and thousands of premature deaths. This forms part of a grim trend: Europe has become a heatwave hotspot, seeing an increase in heatwaves three to four times greater than elsewhere in the midlatitudes. This video examines why, and discusses the future of heatwaves in Europe.

entry.title: Why air pollution is so scary

media:group.media:title: Why air pollution is so scary
media:group.media:description:
Overcome your brain's limitations by learning statistics with Brilliant! https://www.brilliant.org/simonclark
The World Health Organisation says that 7 million people are killed every year by the air they breathe. Why, where, and what can we do about it? Turns out, there are a few reasons we should stop burning fossil fuels...
References 1. https://ourworldindata.org/data-review-air-pollution-deaths 2. https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/cancer 3. https://ourworldindata.org/outdoor-air-pollution#share-exposed-to-air-pollution-above-who-limits 4. https://ourworldindata.org/extreme-poverty#is-the-world-on-track-to-end-extreme-poverty-by-2030 5. https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rates-from-air-pollution 6. https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/ambient-(outdoor)-air-quality-and-health 7. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-23853-y 8. https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1819989116 9. https://ourworldindata.org/outdoor-air-pollution#outdoor-air-pollution-tends-to-rise-with-industrialization-before-falling 10. https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/downloads/report/IPCC_AR6_WGI_SPM_final.pdf
So yeah, spoiler alert, air pollution kills 7 million people a year. And what causes the majority of dangerous air pollution? Humans burning stuff, specifically fossil fuels. Even without their immense impact on global climate, we should be phasing out the use of coal, oil, and natural gas because they are literally killing millions of people every single year. We have the technology to replace fossil fuel use in energy generation with renewables (and nuclear, though that's... complicated here), and wealthy economies need to support low and middle income economies in their efforts to decarbonise (and literally clean up) their energy supply.

entry.title: Three Arguments to Avert Climate Despair

media:group.media:title: Three Arguments to Avert Climate Despair
media:group.media:description:
How I keep hope alive for the future in a time of climate change. Watch Dream the Future on CuriosityStream and get access to Nebula: https://www.curiositystream.com/simonclark
As someone who thinks a lot about climate change, I find it difficult sometimes to stay positive, and it seems I'm not alone. Many people suffer from climate despair, believing that we're just too far gone and that the planet is screwed (insert more forceful expletive if you like). While I can understand why people think this, I don't agree - and in this video I talk about why it's not too late for action, and why there's a lot to be said for not giving up.
Also, I had an absolutely horrific cold while recording this one, sorry.

How do I not give up in the face of climate change? How to avoid climate despair? What is climate despair? Is there any hope in climate change? In this short video essay I talk about the three things that keep me going and not give in to climate despair: the nature of the problem, the nature of the response, and why it makes economic sense to fight climate change. As I say in the video, this isn't to say that I'm hopeful we'll avoid devastating climate change this century: but I'm not hopeless.
